title: Authors and Citation
text: Jingmeng Cui. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cui J (2024). quadVAR: Quadratic Vector Autoregression. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://sciurus365.github.io/quadVAR/, https://github.com/Sciurus365/quadVAR.
code: @Manual{,   title = {quadVAR: Quadratic Vector Autoregression},   author = {Jingmeng Cui},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://sciurus365.github.io/quadVAR/},   url = {https://github.com/Sciurus365/quadVAR}, }

title: Quadratic Vector Autoregression
text: Estimate quadratic vector autoregression models strong hierarchy using RAMP algorithm, compare performance linear models, construct networks partial derivatives.

title: Quadratic Vector Autoregression
text: can install development version quadVAR GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("Sciurus365/quadVAR")

title: Quadratic Vector Autoregression
code: library(quadVAR) set.seed(1614) data <- sim_4_emo(time = 200, sd = 1) plot(data[, "x1"]) qV1 <- quadVAR(data, vars = c("x1", "x2", "x3", "x4")) summary(qV1) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   Model        Sumdf SumIC DiffIC    Weight #>   <chr>        <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 NULL_model       0 3580. 1132.  1.96e-246 #> 2 AR               4 2775.  326.  1.83e- 71 #> 3 VAR             16 2544.   95.4 1.95e- 21 #> 4 VAR_full        16 2544.   95.4 1.95e- 21 #> 5 quadVAR         28 2449.    0   1.00e+  0 #> 6 quadVAR_full    56 2519.   70.1 5.95e- 16 coef(qV1) #>  model effect estimate #>     x1     x1   1.6273 #>     x1     x3   0.0329 #>     x1     x4  -0.0751 #>     x1  x1:x1  -0.1019 #>     x1  x1:x3  -0.1177 #>     x1  x1:x4  -0.1065 #>     x1  x3:x3  -0.0104 #>     x1  x4:x4   0.0157 #>     x2     x1   0.2520 #>     x2     x2   1.4055 #>     x2     x3   0.4096 #>     x2     x4   0.0446 #>     x2  x1:x3  -0.0760 #>     x2  x2:x2  -0.0863 #>     x2  x2:x3  -0.0822 #>     x2  x2:x4  -0.1158 #>     x2  x3:x3  -0.0565 #>     x3     x1  -0.1685 #>     x3     x2   0.1035 #>     x3     x3   1.6050 #>     x3  x1:x3  -0.0769 #>     x3  x2:x2   0.0018 #>     x3  x2:x3  -0.1377 #>     x3  x3:x3  -0.1004 #>     x4     x1   0.0675 #>     x4     x2  -0.1798 #>     x4     x4   0.8196 #>     x4  x1:x4  -0.1138 plot(qV1) #> ℹ The quadVAR model, being nonlinear, generates a network meaningful only for #>   specific variable values. If values are unspecified, the linearization/the #>   plot defaults to 0 (i.e., the mean values of all variables if #>   `value_standardized = TRUE`), but this is not a complete description of the #>   model estimation and may not be meaningful in all cases. #> This message is displayed once every 8 hours. # Compare the estimation with the true model plot(true_model_4_emo()) plot(qV1, value = rep(2.80, 4), value_standardized = FALSE, layout = plot(true_model_4_emo())$layout)

what: Use Block Cross-Validation to Evaluate Models — block_cv
title: Use Block Cross-Validation to Evaluate Models — block_cv
text: function uses block cross-validation evaluate model. data split blocks, model fit one block evaluated remaining block. process repeated block, mean squared error calculated model.

title: Use Block Cross-Validation to Evaluate Models — block_cv
code: block_cv(   data,   dayvar = NULL,   model,   block = 10,   lowerbound = -Inf,   upperbound = Inf,   detail = FALSE,   metric = "MSE" )

title: Use Block Cross-Validation to Evaluate Models — block_cv
text: data data frame. dayvar character string. name variable represents day. required function use dayvar specify time point test block used predict time point test block. dayvar specified, original dataset, please add one constant variable dayvar, specify function passed model. model function. model evaluated. function take data frame first argument return quadVAR object. can , example, function(x) quadVAR(x, vars = c("var1", "var2")) block integer. number blocks use cross-validation. default 10. lowerbound numeric value vector length number variables specifies lower bound predicted values. predicted value less value, replaced value. default value -Inf. upperbound numeric value vector length number variables specifies  upper bound predicted values. predicted value greater value, replaced value. default value Inf. detail logical. TRUE, function return predictions model. default FALSE, returns mean squared error model. metric character vector. metric used evaluate model. default "MSE", calculates mean squared error. option "MAE", calculates mean absolute error. effective detail = FALSE.

title: Use Block Cross-Validation to Evaluate Models — block_cv
text: Depending detail. FALSE, returns list mean squared errors model. TRUE, returns list mean squared errors model, true data, predictions model.

what: Compare estimated model with true model for 4-emotion model — compare_4_emo
title: Compare estimated model with true model for 4-emotion model — compare_4_emo
text: function compares estimated model true model 4-emotion model. prints estimated coefficients true coefficients main effects interaction effects.

title: Compare estimated model with true model for 4-emotion model — compare_4_emo
code: compare_4_emo(model, silent = FALSE)

title: Compare estimated model with true model for 4-emotion model — compare_4_emo
text: model estimated model, using data simulated sim_4_emo(), model estimated using quadVAR(). silent Whether print results.

title: Compare estimated model with true model for 4-emotion model — compare_4_emo
text: Silently return data frame estimated coefficients true coefficients main effects interaction effects, printing results rounded two digits silent = FALSE.

what: Find index of data that satisfies certain conditions — find_index
title: Find index of data that satisfies certain conditions — find_index
text: Find index data satisfies certain conditions

title: Find index of data that satisfies certain conditions — find_index
code: find_index(data, dayvar, beepvar)

title: Find index of data that satisfies certain conditions — find_index
text: data data frame. dayvar String indicating assessment day. Adding argument makes sure first measurement day regressed last measurement previous day. IMPORTANT: add data multiple observations per day. beepvar Optional string indicating assessment beep per day. Adding argument cause non-consecutive beeps treated missing!

title: Find index of data that satisfies certain conditions — find_index
text: list two vectors indices.

what: Extract the adjacency matrix from a quadVAR object. — get_adj_mat
title: Extract the adjacency matrix from a quadVAR object. — get_adj_mat
text: Extract adjacency matrix quadVAR object.

title: Extract the adjacency matrix from a quadVAR object. — get_adj_mat
code: get_adj_mat(model, value)

title: Extract the adjacency matrix from a quadVAR object. — get_adj_mat
text: model quadVAR object. value actual_value output linear_quadVAR_network().

title: Extract the adjacency matrix from a quadVAR object. — get_adj_mat
text: adjacency matrix.

what: Linearize a quadVAR object to produce a network. — linear_quadVAR_network
title: Linearize a quadVAR object to produce a network. — linear_quadVAR_network
text: quadVAR object nonlinear, means relationship variables across different values variables. function linearizes quadVAR object specifying values variables linearized model based , facilitate interpretation. linearized model expressed adjacency matrix, can used produce network.

title: Linearize a quadVAR object to produce a network. — linear_quadVAR_network
code: linear_quadVAR_network(model, value = NULL, value_standardized = TRUE)  # S3 method for linear_quadVAR_network plot(x, interactive = FALSE, ...)

title: Linearize a quadVAR object to produce a network. — linear_quadVAR_network
text: model quadVAR object. value numeric vector length 1 number nodes, specifies values variables linearized model based . length 1, value used variables. default value NULL, case value set 0 calculation, means (value_standardized = TRUE) linearized model based mean values variables. value_standardized logical value specifies whether input value standardized . TRUE, input value regarded standardized value, .e., mean + value * sd (e.g., 0 mean, 1 mean + sd, ...). FALSE, input value regarded raw scale input data. raw dataset already standardized, parameter effect. default value TRUE. x linear_quadVAR_network object. interactive Whether produce interactive plot using shiny (user can change values variables interactively) static plot using qgraph::qgraph(). Default FALSE. ... arguments passed qgraph::qgraph().

title: Linearize a quadVAR object to produce a network. — linear_quadVAR_network
text: linear_quadVAR_network following elements: adj_mat: adjacency matrix linearized network. standardized_value: standardized value linearized model based . actual_value: value raw scale input data. model: input quadVAR object. value_standardized: input.

title: Linearize a quadVAR object to produce a network. — linear_quadVAR_network
text: plot(linear_quadVAR_network): Produce plot linearized quadVAR model. interactive = FALSE, output qgraph object, can used calculate centrality measures using, e.g., qgraph::centrality() qgraph::centralityPlot().

title: Linearize a quadVAR object to produce a network. — linear_quadVAR_network
text: idea linearization function inspired Kroc, E., & Olvera Astivia, O. L. (2023). case curve: Parametric regression second- third-order polynomial functions predictors routine. Psychological Methods. https://doi.org/10.1037/met0000629

what: Make a partial plot of a variable in a model This function takes a quadVAR model as input, and returns a plot of the partial effect of a variable on the dependent variable (controlling all other variables and the intercept), for higher and lower levels of the moderator variable split by the median. — partial_plot
title: Make a partial plot of a variable in a model This function takes a quadVAR model as input, and returns a plot of the partial effect of a variable on the dependent variable (controlling all other variables and the intercept), for higher and lower levels of the moderator variable split by the median. — partial_plot
text: Make partial plot variable model function takes quadVAR model input, returns plot partial effect variable dependent variable (controlling variables intercept), higher lower levels moderator variable split median.

title: Make a partial plot of a variable in a model This function takes a quadVAR model as input, and returns a plot of the partial effect of a variable on the dependent variable (controlling all other variables and the intercept), for higher and lower levels of the moderator variable split by the median. — partial_plot
code: partial_plot(model, y, x, moderator)

title: Make a partial plot of a variable in a model This function takes a quadVAR model as input, and returns a plot of the partial effect of a variable on the dependent variable (controlling all other variables and the intercept), for higher and lower levels of the moderator variable split by the median. — partial_plot
text: model quadVAR model y dependent variable x variable partial effect plotted moderator moderator variable

title: Make a partial plot of a variable in a model This function takes a quadVAR model as input, and returns a plot of the partial effect of a variable on the dependent variable (controlling all other variables and the intercept), for higher and lower levels of the moderator variable split by the median. — partial_plot
text: ggplot object

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: See magrittr::%>% details.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
code: lhs %>% rhs

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: lhs value magrittr placeholder. rhs function call using magrittr semantics.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: result calling rhs(lhs).

what: Predict the values of the dependent variables using the quadVAR model — predict.quadVAR
title: Predict the values of the dependent variables using the quadVAR model — predict.quadVAR
text: Predict values dependent variables using quadVAR model

title: Predict the values of the dependent variables using the quadVAR model — predict.quadVAR
code: # S3 method for quadVAR predict(   object,   newdata = NULL,   donotpredict = NULL,   lowerbound = -Inf,   upperbound = Inf,   ... )

title: Predict the values of the dependent variables using the quadVAR model — predict.quadVAR
text: object quadVAR object. newdata data frame tibble containing least values independent variables, dayvar, beepvar (used model estimation). NULL, original data used fit model used. donotpredict IMPLEMENTED YET! character vector model names used prediction. Possible options include "AR", "VAR", "VAR_full", "quadVAR_full", "all_others", NULL default. set "all_others", quadVAR model estimated. datasets large number variables, may set parameter "quadVAR_full" save time. lowerbound numeric value vector length number variables specifies lower bound predicted values. predicted value less value, replaced value. default value -Inf. upperbound numeric value vector length number variables specifies  upper bound predicted values. predicted value greater value, replaced value. default value Inf. ... arguments passed RAMP::predict.RAMP() function.

title: Predict the values of the dependent variables using the quadVAR model — predict.quadVAR
text: data frame tibble containing predicted values dependent variables. value predicted (e.g., corresponding previous time point data), NA.

what: Estimate lag-1 quadratic vector autoregression models — quadVAR
title: Estimate lag-1 quadratic vector autoregression models — quadVAR
text: function estimate regularized nonlinear quadratic vector autoregression models strong hierarchy using RAMP::RAMP() algorithm, also compare linear AR, regularized VAR, unregularized (full) VAR quadratic VAR models.

title: Estimate lag-1 quadratic vector autoregression models — quadVAR
code: quadVAR(   data,   vars,   dayvar = NULL,   beepvar = NULL,   penalty = "LASSO",   tune = "EBIC",   donotestimate = NULL,   SIS_options = list(),   RAMP_options = list() )  # S3 method for quadVAR print(x, ...)  # S3 method for quadVAR summary(object, ...)  # S3 method for quadVAR coef(object, ...)  # S3 method for coef_quadVAR print(   x,   use_actual_names = TRUE,   abbr = FALSE,   minlength = 3,   omit_zero = TRUE,   digits = 2,   row.names = FALSE,   ... )  # S3 method for quadVAR plot(x, value = NULL, value_standardized = TRUE, interactive = FALSE, ...)

title: Estimate lag-1 quadratic vector autoregression models — quadVAR
text: data tibble, data.frame, matrix represents time series vectors, row time step. vars character vector variable names used model. dayvar String indicating assessment day. Adding argument makes sure first measurement day regressed last measurement previous day. IMPORTANT: add data multiple observations per day. beepvar Optional string indicating assessment beep per day. Adding argument cause non-consecutive beeps treated missing! penalty penalty used linear regularized VAR models. Possible options include "LASSO", "SCAD", "MCP", "LASSO" default. tune Tuning parameter selection method. Possible options include "AIC", "BIC", "EBIC", "EBIC" default. donotestimate character vector model names estimated. Possible options include, "NULL_model", "AR", "VAR", "VAR_full", "quadVAR_full", "all_others", NULL default. set "all_others", quadVAR model estimated. datasets large number variables, may set parameter "quadVAR_full" save time. SIS_options list parameters SIS::tune.fit() function. used regularized  VAR models. RAMP_options list parameters RAMP::RAMP() function. used nonlinear quadratic VAR model. ... print.quadVAR, additional arguments passed print.coef_quadVAR(). print.coef_quadVAR, additional arguments passed print.data.frame(). object, x quadVAR object. (print.coef_quadVAR, coef_quadVAR object returned coef.quadVAR().) use_actual_names Logical. TRUE, actual variable names used output. FALSE, names "X1", "X2", etc., used output. Default TRUE. abbr Logical. TRUE, output abbreviated. Default FALSE. minlength minimum length abbreviations. omit_zero Logical. TRUE, coefficients zero omitted. Default FALSE. digits minimum number significant digits used: see     print.default. row.names logical (character vector), indicating whether (    ) row names printed. value numeric vector length 1 number nodes, specifies values variables linearized model based . length 1, value used variables. default value NULL, case value set 0 calculation, means (value_standardized = TRUE) linearized model based mean values variables. value_standardized logical value specifies whether input value standardized . TRUE, input value regarded standardized value, .e., mean + value * sd (e.g., 0 mean, 1 mean + sd, ...). FALSE, input value regarded raw scale input data. raw dataset already standardized, parameter effect. default value TRUE. interactive Whether produce interactive plot using shiny (user can change values variables interactively) static plot using qgraph::qgraph(). Default FALSE.

title: Estimate lag-1 quadratic vector autoregression models — quadVAR
text: quadVAR object contains following elements: NULL_model: list NULL models variable. AR_model: list linear AR models variable. VAR_model: list regularized VAR models variable. VAR_full_model: list unregularized (full) VAR models variable. quadVAR_model: list regularized nonlinear quadratic VAR models variable. quadVAR_full_model: list unregularized (full) nonlinear quadratic VAR models variable. data,vars,penalty,tune,SIS_options,RAMP_options: input arguments. data_x,data_y: data directly used modeling.

title: Estimate lag-1 quadratic vector autoregression models — quadVAR
text: print(quadVAR): Print coefficients quadVAR object. See coef.quadVAR() print.coef_quadVAR() details. summary(quadVAR): Summary quadVAR object. Different IC definitions used different packages (differ constant) unified make comparable . coef(quadVAR): Extract coefficients quadVAR object. plot(quadVAR): Produce plot linearized quadVAR model. Equivalent first produce linear quadVAR network using linear_quadVAR_network(), use plot.linear_quadVAR_network().

title: Estimate lag-1 quadratic vector autoregression models — quadVAR
text: print(coef_quadVAR): Print coefficients quadVAR object.

title: Estimate lag-1 quadratic vector autoregression models — quadVAR
code: set.seed(1614) data <- sim_4_emo(time = 200, sd = 1) plot(data[, "x1"])  qV1 <- quadVAR(data, vars = c("x1", "x2", "x3", "x4")) summary(qV1) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   Model        Sumdf SumIC DiffIC    Weight #>   <chr>        <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 NULL_model       0 3580. 1132.  1.96e-246 #> 2 AR               4 2775.  326.  1.83e- 71 #> 3 VAR             16 2544.   95.4 1.95e- 21 #> 4 VAR_full        16 2544.   95.4 1.95e- 21 #> 5 quadVAR         28 2449.    0   1.00e+  0 #> 6 quadVAR_full    56 2519.   70.1 5.95e- 16 coef(qV1) #>  model effect estimate #>     x1     x1   1.6273 #>     x1     x3   0.0329 #>     x1     x4  -0.0751 #>     x1  x1:x1  -0.1019 #>     x1  x1:x3  -0.1177 #>     x1  x1:x4  -0.1065 #>     x1  x3:x3  -0.0104 #>     x1  x4:x4   0.0157 #>     x2     x1   0.2520 #>     x2     x2   1.4055 #>     x2     x3   0.4096 #>     x2     x4   0.0446 #>     x2  x1:x3  -0.0760 #>     x2  x2:x2  -0.0863 #>     x2  x2:x3  -0.0822 #>     x2  x2:x4  -0.1158 #>     x2  x3:x3  -0.0565 #>     x3     x1  -0.1685 #>     x3     x2   0.1035 #>     x3     x3   1.6050 #>     x3  x1:x3  -0.0769 #>     x3  x2:x2   0.0018 #>     x3  x2:x3  -0.1377 #>     x3  x3:x3  -0.1004 #>     x4     x1   0.0675 #>     x4     x2  -0.1798 #>     x4     x4   0.8196 #>     x4  x1:x4  -0.1138 plot(qV1) #> ℹ The quadVAR model, being nonlinear, generates a network meaningful only for #>   specific variable values. If values are unspecified, the linearization/the #>   plot defaults to 0 (i.e., the mean values of all variables if #>   `value_standardized = TRUE`), but this is not a complete description of the #>   model estimation and may not be meaningful in all cases. #> This message is displayed once every 8 hours.  # Compare the estimation with the true model plot(true_model_4_emo())  plot(qV1, value = 0, value_standardized = FALSE, layout = plot(true_model_4_emo())$layout)

title: Transform a quadVAR object to a list of dynamic equations. — quadVAR_to_dyn_eqns
text: model quadVAR object. minus_self Whether subtract term equation. TRUE, equation form (0 =)  ... - X1; FALSE, equation form (X1 = )....

title: Transform a quadVAR object to a list of dynamic equations. — quadVAR_to_dyn_eqns
text: list dynamic equations characters. can also use rlang::parse_expr() parse expressions.

title: Simulate a 4-emotion model — sim_4_emo
text: function simulates 4-emotion model nonlinear, bistable, discrete, (almost) centered zero. Adapted model described van de Leemput et al. (2014).

title: Simulate a 4-emotion model — sim_4_emo
Simulate a 4-emotion model — sim_4_emo
text: time number time steps simulate. init vector initial values four variables. Default c(1.36, 1.36, 4.89, 4.89), one stable states model. sd standard deviation noise.

title: Simulate a 4-emotion model — sim_4_emo
text: matrix simulated data.

title: Simulate a 4-emotion model — sim_4_emo
text: van de Leemput, . ., Wichers, M., Cramer, . O., Borsboom, D., Tuerlinckx, F., Kuppens, P., ... & Scheffer, M. (2014). Critical slowing early warning onset termination depression. Proceedings National Academy Sciences, 111(1), 87-92.

title: True model for 4-emotion model — true_model_4_emo
text: function generate true model 4-emotion model. can used compare estimated model true model, plot true model.

title: True model for 4-emotion model — true_model_4_emo
code: true_model_4_emo(...)  # S3 method for true_model_4_emo coef(object, ...)  # S3 method for true_model_4_emo print(x, which = NULL, ...)

title: True model for 4-emotion model — true_model_4_emo
text: ... use. object true_model_4_emo object. x true_model_4_emo object. model print . four models total, corresponding four variables.

title: True model for 4-emotion model — true_model_4_emo
text: true_model_4_emo object. NULL, prints true model.

title: True model for 4-emotion model — true_model_4_emo
text: coef(true_model_4_emo): function returns coefficients 4-emotion model. also used functions generate linearized version true model make plots. returns list coefficients 4-emotion model, format coef.quadVAR() print(true_model_4_emo): function prints true model 4-emotion model format RAMP::RAMP(), help users compare true model estimated model.

title: True model for 4-emotion model — true_model_4_emo

what: Using the glmnet and ncvreg packages, fits a Generalized Linear Model or Cox Proportional Hazards Model using various methods for choosing the regularization parameter λ — tune.fit
title: Using the glmnet and ncvreg packages, fits a Generalized Linear Model or Cox Proportional Hazards Model using various methods for choosing the regularization parameter λ — tune.fit
text: function modified SIS::tune.fit(). used tune regularization parameter regularized VAR models. wrapper used following reasons. original SIS::tune.fit() function return value information criteria like use. use ncvreg package exclusively (removed code using glmnet package). make result consistent, also ncvreg package better support calculation information criteria. also removed generalized linear model (GLM) option, cross-validation option use . use stats::AIC() stats::BIC() instead ones using SIS:::loglik() make calculation methods consistent. added ... allow user pass additional arguments ncvreg::ncvreg() function.

title: Using the glmnet and ncvreg packages, fits a Generalized Linear Model or Cox Proportional Hazards Model using various methods for choosing the regularization parameter λ — tune.fit
code: tune.fit(   x,   y,   family = "gaussian",   penalty = c("SCAD", "MCP", "lasso"),   concavity.parameter = switch(penalty, SCAD = 3.7, 3),   tune = c("aic", "bic", "ebic"),   type.measure = c("deviance", "class", "auc", "mse", "mae"),   gamma.ebic = 1,   ... )

title: Using the glmnet and ncvreg packages, fits a Generalized Linear Model or Cox Proportional Hazards Model using various methods for choosing the regularization parameter λ — tune.fit
text: x design matrix, dimensions n * p, without intercept. row observation vector. y response vector dimension n * 1. Quantitative family='gaussian', non-negative counts family='poisson', binary (0-1) family='binomial'. family='cox', y object class Surv, provided function Surv() package survival. family Response type (see ). penalty penalty applied regularized likelihood subproblems. 'SCAD' (default), 'MCP', 'lasso' provided. concavity.parameter tuning parameter used adjust concavity SCAD/MCP penalty. Default 3.7 SCAD 3 MCP. tune Method selecting regularization parameter along solution path penalized likelihood problem. Options provide final model include tune='cv', tune='aic', tune='bic', tune='ebic'. See references end details. type.measure Loss use cross-validation. Currently five options, available models. default type.measure='deviance', uses squared-error gaussian models (also equivalent type.measure='mse' case), deviance logistic poisson regression, partial-likelihood Cox model. type.measure='class' type.measure='auc' apply logistic regression give misclassification error area ROC curve, respectively. type.measure='mse' type.measure='mae' (mean absolute error) can used models except 'cox'; measure deviation fitted mean response. penalty='SCAD' penalty='MCP', type.measure='deviance' available. gamma.ebic Specifies parameter Extended BIC criterion penalizing size corresponding model space. default gamma.ebic=1. See references end details. ... additional arguments passed ncvreg::ncvreg() function.

title: Using the glmnet and ncvreg packages, fits a Generalized Linear Model or Cox Proportional Hazards Model using various methods for choosing the regularization parameter λ — tune.fit
text: Returns object ix vector indices nonzero coefficients selected maximum penalized likelihood procedure tune method choosing regularization parameter. a0 intercept final model selected tune. beta vector coefficients final model selected tune. fit fitted penalized regression object. lambda corresponding lambda final model. lambda.ind index solution path final model.

title: Using the glmnet and ncvreg packages, fits a Generalized Linear Model or Cox Proportional Hazards Model using various methods for choosing the regularization parameter λ — tune.fit
text: Original description SIS::tune.fit(): function fits generalized linear model Cox proportional hazards model via penalized maximum likelihood, available penalties indicated glmnet ncvreg packages. Instead providing whole regularization solution path, function returns solution unique value λ, one optimizing criterion specified tune.

title: Using the glmnet and ncvreg packages, fits a Generalized Linear Model or Cox Proportional Hazards Model using various methods for choosing the regularization parameter λ — tune.fit
text: Jerome Friedman Trevor Hastie Rob Tibshirani (2010) Regularization Paths Generalized Linear Models Via Coordinate Descent. Journal Statistical Software, 33(1), 1-22. Noah Simon Jerome Friedman Trevor Hastie Rob Tibshirani (2011) Regularization Paths Cox's Proportional Hazards Model Via Coordinate Descent. Journal Statistical Software, 39(5), 1-13. Patrick Breheny Jian Huang (2011) Coordiante Descent Algorithms Nonconvex Penalized Regression, Applications Biological Feature Selection. Annals Applied Statistics, 5, 232-253. Hirotogu Akaike (1973) Information Theory Extension Maximum Likelihood Principle. Proceedings 2nd International Symposium Information Theory, BN Petrov F Csaki (eds.), 267-281. Gideon Schwarz (1978) Estimating Dimension Model. Annals Statistics, 6, 461-464. Jiahua Chen Zehua Chen (2008) Extended Bayesian Information Criteria Model Selection Large Model Spaces. Biometrika, 95, 759-771.

title: Using the glmnet and ncvreg packages, fits a Generalized Linear Model or Cox Proportional Hazards Model using various methods for choosing the regularization parameter λ — tune.fit
text: Jianqing Fan, Yang Feng, Diego Franco Saldana, Richard Samworth, Yichao Wu

title: Using the glmnet and ncvreg packages, fits a Generalized Linear Model or Cox Proportional Hazards Model using various methods for choosing the regularization parameter λ — tune.fit
code: if (FALSE) { set.seed(0) data("leukemia.train", package = "SIS") y.train <- leukemia.train[, dim(leukemia.train)[2]] x.train <- as.matrix(leukemia.train[, -dim(leukemia.train)[2]]) x.train <- standardize(x.train) model <- tune.fit(x.train[, 1:3500], y.train, family = "binomial", tune = "bic") model$ix model$a0 model$beta }
